pronunciation: REPROBATE, [Latin reprobatus, reprobo, to disallow; re and probo, to prove.]

definitions.text:
1. Not enduring proof or trial; not of standard purity or fineness; disallowed; rejected.
REPROBATE silver shall men call them, because the Lord hath rejected them. Jeremiah 6:30.
2. Abandoned sin; lost virtue or grace.
They profess that they know God, but works deny him, being abominable disobedient, every good work reprobate Titus 1:16.
3. Abandoned error, or apostasy. 2 Timothy 3:8.
REP'ROBATE,

person abandoned sin; one lost virtue religion.
I acknowledge myself reprobate villain, traitor the king.
REP'ROBATE,

1. To disapprove with detestation or marks of extreme dislike; reject. It expresses more than disapprove or disallow. We disapprove of slight faults improprieties; we reprobate what mean or criminal.
2. In milder sense, disallow.
Such answer as this, reprobated disallowed of law.
3. To abandon wickedness eternal destruction.
4. To abandon his sentence, without hope of pardon.
Drive him out reprobated exile.
